properties.title: Klaus
properties.description:
Klaus Advanced Computing Building

  • -Funded in 2000 by Chris Klaus, a GT Grad
  • -Officially opened October 26, 2006
  • -Occupies the land where the health center used to be, new health center (stamps) is by the campus recreation center
  • -Home of the Binary Bridge, named for the glass paneling with the word klaus written over and over in binary

properties.title: CULC
properties.description:
Clough Undergraduate Learning Center

  • -In planning for more than 10 years
  • -Inaugurated August 2011
  • -8.75 million in funding was provided by an anonymous donor
  • -Named after the campus president at the time
  • -Features Solar panels, a rain collection cistern, daylight harvesting and motion sensor lighting, and efficient ventilation systems as part of green initiatives

properties.title: CoC
properties.description:
College of Computing

  • -Opened October 26, 2006
  • -Linked with Klaus via the Binary Bridge
  • -Formally home to two schools, the School of Interactive Computing and the School of Computer Science
  • -The programs associated with the CoC are consistently top 10 in the nation in their respective categories

properties.title: Student Center
properties.description:
Campus Student Center

  • -Home of the Campaniele, formerly featured in the Georgia Tech Logo
  • -Also known as the Wenn Building
  • -Recently renovated, making modifications to the Wenn building to accommodate more students
  • -Amenities and Organizations: Tech Recreation, Wrek Radio, Dining Halls, Miscellaneous Student Org Spaces, Student Govt. Assn., Large Theatre, and more

properties.title: Exhibition Hall
properties.description:
The Exhibition Hall

  • -All rooms are named after local streets or areas
  • -Regularly hosts large scale events
  • -Built as part of the effort to revitalize the campus center along with the student center

properties.title: Bobby Dodd Stadium
properties.description:
Bobby Dodd Stadium

  • -Home to the yellow jackets in rough form since 1905 and as an official stadium since 1913
  • -The stadium itself was built around the historic grant field, named for hugh inman grant
  • -Named after the titular Bobby Dodd, who has the most wins of any coach in yellow jacket history
  • -Has a total seating capacity of 55,000 people, up from the original 7,000 by a wide margin. The all-time high was 58,121.

properties.title: Brittain Dining Hall
properties.description:
Brittain Dining Hall

  • -Primary dining hall on east campus
  • -Opened in 1928, renovated in 1964, 1999, 2002, and 2007
  • -Two dining floors, but the second one is often restricted due to student`s innovative interpretation of the phrase `food on the fly`
  • -The entrance is marked by a `Georgia School of Technology` seal, showing how old this building is

properties.title: North Avenue Apartments
properties.description:
North Avenue Apartments

  • -Transferred from Georgia State to Georgia Tech in 2007
  • -Originally constructed for the 1996 summer olympics, opening in 1995 as housing for athletes and journalists
  • -Split into 4 segments, North, East, South, and West. It is widely agreed upon that `West is Best` and the courtyard these segments surround is the final destination for an unknown, non-suspicious end of semester tradition

properties.title: Fitten Residence Hall
properties.description:
Fitten Residence Hall

  • -Built in 1972
  • -Houses 128 students
  • -Part of the Georgia Tech Freshman Experience

properties.title: The Kendeda Building
properties.description:
The Kendeda Building

  • -The Greenest Classroom building in Georgia
  • -28th Building in the World to earn the Living Building Challenge certification
  • -Net energy and water positive
  • -Incorporated salvage in its construction, diverting more waste from landfills than it sent

properties.title: Howey Physics Buidling
properties.description:
Howey Physics Building

  • -Home to the Physics Department, one of the original eight departments created
  • -Built in 1967
  • -If looked at from the top, the building resembles an H in structure
  • -Named after Joseph Howey, director of the school of physics from 1935 to 1963
